data.title: Unofficial European Club Champions?
data.meta_description: Using the rules as I understand them, I came up with the following for European Club competitions. The waters are muddied a bit when two-leg ties are to be considered, but that makes it more fun! Not
data.text:
Post by peteyboy on

Using the rules as I understand them, I came up with the following for European Club competitions. The waters are muddied a bit when two-leg ties are to be considered, but that makes it more fun! Not having access to the relevant domestic games means it's of necessity restricted to European competition games only. I had to make a few arbitrary decisions which I've explained between the results and the rankings. Anyway....

· 1958: Despite beating Real in the second leg, Vasas lost the tie, but retained their unofficial champions’ status until their next European tie, four years later.

· 1969: Despite beating AC Milan in the second leg, United lost the tie, but retained their unofficial champions’ status until their next European tie, eight years later.

· 1977: Despite beating Juventus in the second leg, Shakhtyor lost the tie, but retained their unofficial champions’ status until their next European tie, two years later.

· 1981: Despite beating Valencia in the second leg, Boavista lost the tie, but retained their unofficial champions’ status until their next European tie, four years later.

· 1986: Despite beating Real in the second leg, Cologne lost the tie, but retained their unofficial champions’ status until their next European tie, three years later.

· 1988: Stuttgart and Real Sociedad each won their home legs 1-0, and Stuttgart were awarded the tie, either by lots or penalties, but as Sociedad won the later leg, they retain their unofficial champions’ status until their next European tie, two seasons later.

· 1993: Following being found guilty of illegal affairs, Marseille were subsequently stripped of their official title as champions, and banned for a number of years. However, they retain their unofficial champions’ status until their next European tie, six seasons later.

All games are European Cup / European Champions League except where signified:

EFC = European Fairs / UEFA Cup

CWC = European Cup-Winners Cup

Winners / Retainers of Title are shown first, irrespective of game’s location.
